Official Name: The People's Democratic Republic of Algeria

Adjectival Name: Antiguan; Barbudan (as appropriate); 'Antigua and Barbuda' (as in 'Antigua and Barbuda Government')
Bosnia and Herzegovinian (which may be shortened to 'Bosnian' in informal contexts)

Official Name: The Republic of the Union of Myanmar

Name for Citizen: Citizen of the Central African Republic
Citizen of the Republic of the Congo
Adjectival Name: of the Republic of the Congo; Congolese
Notes: It is important not to confuse Congo with Congo (Democratic Republic).  The form 'Congolese' should only be used where the context makes it clear which specific country is intended.

Official Name: The Democratic Republic of the Congo
Name for Citizen: Citizen of The Democratic Republic of the Congo
Adjectival Name: of the Democratic Republic of the Congo; Congolese
Notes: It is important not to confuse Congo (Democratic Republic) with Congo.  The form 'Congolese' should only be used where the context makes it clear which specific country is intended.
It is important not to confuse Dominica with the Dominican Republic.
It is important not to confuse the Dominican Republic with Dominica.
Salvador should not be used by itself for the country.

Official Name: The Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia

Adjectival Name: Fiji; of Fiji; Fijian (as in 'Fijian Government')
Ivorian; Ivory Coast (as in 'Ivory Coast Government')

Official Name: The Democratic People's Republic of Korea
Name for Citizen: Citizen of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea; Citizen of the DPRK

Notes: The name quoted is that used by the state itself, and is used by the UK for bilateral agreements and all bilateral purposes.  The name used by the UK when formally establishing diplomatic relations was 'The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia', and this is used in multilateral contexts.  The designation used by the United Nations to refer to Macedonia is 'The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia', listed under 'T' alphabetically.  (This is a temporary arrangement until Macedonia and Greece find a permanent solution to this name issue.)

St Lucian; St Lucia (as in 'St Lucia Government')

Name for Citizen: Citizen of Sao Tome and Principe

Name for Citizen: Citizen of the United Arab Emirates
Notes: The United Arab Emirates is a state comprising Abu Dhabi, Dubai, Sharjah, Umm al Qaiwain, Ajman, Ras al Khaimah and Fujairah.

Adjectival Name: United States; American can be used in informal contexts
Notes: Usage of 'America' and 'American' instead of 'United States' should be avoided unless the context makes clear that 'United States' is intended.

Adjectival Name: Vatican or Apostolic (or Papal) according to context
Notes: The Holy See is the actual seat (i.e. residence) of the Pope, but is the term generally used to indicate the Pope together with those associated with him in the government of the Roman Catholic Church at its headquarters.  The Holy See exercises a traditional right to send and receive Ambassadors, to conclude treaties and to participate in international affairs.  Since this legal or political personality is more important than the Pope's temporal sovereignty, it is the 'Holy See' which normally takes part in international relations, is represented at international conferences, and is a party to international conventions.  The only exceptions are questions, such as those dealt with by the Universal Postal Union, where the body interested is clearly the administration of 'the Vatican City'.  Her Majesty's Representative is accordingly Her Majesty's Ambassador to the Holy See, not to the Vatican City State.  Citizenship is of the Vatican, but the Vatican uses three different types of passport: Holy See Diplomatic passports, Holy See Service passports, and Vatican City State passports.  Holders of the first two types of passport, which include all members of the Papal diplomatic service, are not usually citizens of the Vatican City State; when they retire or leave the service of the Holy See they revert to their original nationality.  The correct adjective to use depends on the context.  For example, the diplomatic representation of the Holy See should be described as Apostolic (or less correctly Papal) Nunciature, while on the other hand it is correct to speak of the Vatican radio or of a Vatican stamp.
